message.raw:
renamed state to mode in some instances to make the distinction between states and modes clearer!

Added a delete_stale_states parameter to @define_state which will pull the most recent state out of the queue of adjacent identical statefunctions.

Eg, if the statefunctions in the queue are: [a,a,a,b,a,a,c,a,a,a,a]
and a is defined wth delete_stale_states=True,
then we will execute the 3rd a, then b, then skip the next a, execute the a before the c, execute c, and then execute the last a.
This is designed so that multiple calls to program_device only runs the most recent one, which is especially important on slow devices like the RfBlaster which can take ~5s to program in manual mode. This replaces the hack previously used in the RfBlaster which ignored calls to program_device if we already had 2 in the queue (the number in the queue was kept track of manually within the tab)

message.raw:
Modified the StateQueue to store the function rather than the name of teh function to be looked up later (this also avoids poluting the class namespace with _funcname copies of the function).

Made timeouts more robust. The call to execute_timeout will occur in every mode, but the statefunction will only be queued up if the current mode is one of the statefunctions allowed modes. The timeout is always requeued, regardless of the curret mode.

message.raw:
device_base_class.py/tab_frame.ui
Started too build in the remote value check code.

tab_base_classes.py
Added in smart programming
rewrote timeout code

This is a commit before an even more significant rewrite of the timeout adding code. I've realised there will be bugs with this given the implementation of various modes, which could potentially lead to the buildup of many statefunctions due to the fact that the timeout_add function can run in all states, but the statefunction you want running every x seconds may stay and build up in the queue if it can only run in manual_mode and we are in another mode.

Adjusted the code to reflect the changes to the UI file

In tab_frame.ui
Made the title, restart and refresh smart programming widgets part of every tab
Will make it possible to hide the smart programming if the device doesn't use it (maybe disable and force check the box for consistency?)

In device_base_class.py (ALL UNTESTED)
Wrote a class to try and abstract away a lot of the boring stuff we do with the UI in every device GUI class.
Widget generation is more automatic, and it should even be able to place widgets for you.
Channels and their capabilities are defined in a dictionary (kind of like a definition through meta data)
Added standard functions for transitioning between modes, etc.
I expect most devices to subclass this, and at a minimum, overwrite the initialise_GUI() method, which should call some of the widget generation classes previously described. A worker class can then be made to match the standard worker process calls I've used here (like transition_to_manual, etc)

message.raw:
Modified tab_base_classes to use the yield command (along with generators) to queue work to child processes.
This removes the need to have a do_after function
This allows the user to queue work more than once in a state
This provides more readable code (queue_work would execute after the entire function before, now it executes at the point you call it)

The queue manager is being moved into a class within queue.py

message.raw:
NI cards now require an argument MAX_name to their constructor in labscript. This is the name that will be used to tell the NI DAQMX library which card we're talking to, and does not need to match the device's name in your labscript code.

Previously the device's labscript name had to be the MAX name. But now we're making this in line with the rest of labscript, where a device's name and directions for communicating it are stored separately.

message.raw:
a (hopefully temporary) fix for bug #610.
This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

message.raw: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.

message.raw:
Reversed the order of the 'set units' and 'set value' steps in restoring front panel settings for widgets.

This is because 'set units' doesn't actually happen immediately, it queues up a callback. So by running it first, it puts the object in an inconsistent state where self.units has been updated, but the GUI does not yet reflect this. This causes incorrect results when the set_value method runs, and uses self.units to find out what the units are. It thinks the units have been updated, so it sets the value in the new units.
Then the units actually get updated when the queued up callback runs soon after. This converts the value into the new units -- even though it was already in the new units! The conversion thus results in a nonsese result.

By simply swapping these steps the problem is resolved. The value gets set (in base units), then the units are changed to the non-base units, and the value is converted.

message.raw: BLACS now uses subproc_utils.zmq_get to submit files to lyse and to check if lyse is responding. BLACS does not yet use a subproc_utils.ZMQServer as its own web server, but it will soon. That change will then require runmanager to switch to using zmq_get as well, so those two changes will be made in tandem.

message.raw:
refs #476

Fixed a few problems with holding down the up/down button on the spinbuttons which would cause multiple programs to be queued up, which at the completion of each, update the widget to the value the novatech contains, affectively preventing you from stepping through the value at a rate faster than it could program the novatech!

Also cleaned up the novatech  __init__ code a bit (changes based on the Pulseblaster init code)!

message.raw:
Resolves #476
refs #345

The NovatechDDS9m now compares front panel values to device values and gives the user the opportunity to choose on a per channel basis which values they want (either front panel or device).

This also makes it easy to restore the Novatech channel lock state, units, step size as I don't have to write a special case to do it!

This feature also makes it easy to restore values to your novatech if it loses power!

The front panel is greyed out while waiting for the user to decide which values to accept.
Running a buffered experiment while the front panel is greyed out is fine, it just ignores both the remote and front panel values as they'll be overwritten at the end of the run anyway!

The pretend "gate" has also been removed as we should have most channels under digital gate control anyway!

message.raw:
Made some changes to the way things work for the RfBlaster.

Static updates still do not work (reason unknown, will debug with vlad)
I expect this means buffered updates will not work either!

What does work is the consistency check between the front panel values in BLACS and the RfBlaster values. This now detects if they don't match, and warns the user, giving them the option of pushing or pulling values from the device on a per channel basis.

Will apply this to the Novatech DDS9m soon, which will solve a long standing issue (refs #476 and refs #345)

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where I created the settings dictionary entry if it existed, but didn't populate the required keys (such as base_value, etc). Thus, if the widget did not undergo a value change, unit change, lock state change and step size change, the settings dictionary would not be populated correctly for the save_front_panel_state function and BLACS would through exceptions at various points in time, including when attempting to close, which would then leave BLACS in an unresponsive state.

Fixed a bug where digital output objects were not saving their state because I didn't save the settings dictionary as a object attribute (continuity was not preserved across restarts)

Fixed a bug where the step size would not be updated in the settings dictionary when changing the unit (only an issue if you change unit, and then restart the tab)

Fixed a bug where I was saving the step size in the setings dictionary in terms on the current unit, not the base unit (only an issue if you use units and then restart the tab)
message.html:
Fixed a bug where I created the settings dictionary entry if it existed, but didn't populate the required keys (such as base_value, etc). Thus, if the widget did not undergo a value change, unit change, lock state change and step size change, the settings dictionary would not be populated correctly for the save_front_panel_state function and BLACS would through exceptions at various points in time, including when attempting to close, which would then leave BLACS in an unresponsive state.

Fixed a bug where digital output objects were not saving their state because I didn't save the settings dictionary as a object attribute (continuity was not preserved across restarts)

Fixed a bug where the step size would not be updated in the settings dictionary when changing the unit (only an issue if you change unit, and then restart the tab)

Fixed a bug where I was saving the step size in the setings dictionary in terms on the current unit, not the base unit (only an issue if you use units and then restart the tab)

message.raw:
Fixed a bug with the new deliberate specification of board_number in the connection table.

If the connection table was defined as:
PulseBlaster('pb_0',board_number=1)
PulseBlaster('pb_1',board_number=0)
then the pulseblasters would be given each others pulse sequences!
Fortunately, this never happened, because we always assigned pb_0 as board 0, etc!

This error was because we picked the group out of the HDF5 file based on the board number (which used to be hard coded and matched to the device name). We now pick the group based on the device name, which is what we should ALWAYS do with every device.

message.raw:
refs #534 (BIAS can read the connection table h5 file location from here)

refs #546

Modified BLACS to use a new labconfig file located in C:\labconfig\<hostname>.ini

Note that you will need to configure the ini file, and place the connection table.py/.h5 and BLACS settings files in the correct places before starting BLACS or else you will run into undefined behaviour depending on which part you did not configure correctly.

You may also lose front panel state if you do not do it correctly!

Added required_params argument to LabConfig class instantiation so that an exception is raised if certain parameters are not defined in the config file that are required. Obviously does not check whether the paths actually point to useful files!!

message.raw:
Modified The pulseblaster to use Hz as the Base Unit (will mess up your front panel values by 10^6, so be warned!!)

Changed the number of decimal places to display (this is a little messy, since it may limit the precision you can specify on the front panel if you don't use Base units...will look into a nicer fix)

Made the Pulseblaster and novatechdds9m classes use the BLACS_connection column in the connection table instead of parameters being hardcoded in main.pyw!

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where I broke the entire statemachine in the last bugfix. This was due to the use of a multiprocessing.Queue for passing the statemachine function arguments. These queues cannot hold unpicklable objects, such as functions. So BLACS crashed when a function was passed to statemachine_timeout_add (the pulseblaster's status checking).

We now are using a Queue.Queue for the statemachine.

This also means we should be passing around actual functions instad of their names. I'll make this change soon.
